trial_identification.studytitle: Liver and muscle triglyceride and muscle metabolic rate in overweight and type 2 diabetes
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect of aerobic exercise training on changes in muscle metabolic rate, liver and muscle triglyceride concentration in overweight adults and adults with type 2 diabetes

interventions.interventions: Four week progressive aerobic exercise training versus sedentary control. Participants will undertake supervised cycle ergometer exercise 4 days per week. Week 1: 30 min per day (as 2 x 15 min bouts at 50% VO2max); Week 2: 45 min per day (as 30 min + 15 min bouts at 50% VO2max); Week 3: 60 min per day (as 2 x 30 min at 60% VO2max); Week 4; 60 min per day (as 2 x 30 min or 60 min continuous at 65% VO2max).
interventions.comparator: Volunteers recruited to the 'sedentary control' group will receive no treatment/intervention as they are healthy individuals.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in muscle and liver triglyceride concentration

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed by incremental exercise test after 4 weeks of training (versus baseline).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Inclusion for overweight and type 2 diabetes groups: Body mass index (BMI)>25 kg/m2 with or without type 2 diabetes. Inclusion for lean non-diabetic group = BMI < 25.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: BMI>30, advanced cardiovascular disease, musculoskeletal ailment

ethicsAndSummary.summary: 3 groups of individuals will be recruited for the research: a. lean healthy individuals b. overweight individuals with type 2 diabetes c. overweight (matched to b) non-diabetic individuals. All groups will be assessed and compared for muscle and liver triglyceride concentration and muscle metabolic rate to address the hypothesis that overweight and/or type 2 diabetes is associated with low metabolic rate and elevated liver and muscle triglyceride content. Individuals in groups b and c will then undertake 4 weeks of aerobic exercise training to determine if training influences these metabolic 'abnormalities'. This will be determined by comparing these measures AFTER 4 training weeks with those determined PRE-TRAINING.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: University of Sydney Human Research Ethics Committee
